This is my favourite game ever. What else is there to say?

Ok, so I downloaded ADOM in all its ASCII glory back in the mid-nineties. Since then, I've died a lot. I've been killed by an exploding frog, I've been crushed by my own inventory, I've turned into a pile of chaos goo. I've had my real-life sleep disturbed by nightmares of bright green Hs and dark grey Ls. Eventually I managed a win, then another. I still die a lot.

There's no other game I could imagine playing for two decades. Adom is deep, challenging, frustrating and addictive. And it's still my favourite game ever.

One of the most popular roguelikes of all time has finally made it to Steam. There's a reason why ADOM and ToME4 usually fight it out for #1 and #2 on the Roguelike of the Year awards and that's because they are both bloody good and worth your cash.

ADOM is one of the most challenging games I have encountered. The mechanics are deep and rewarding for those that play and discover. Death, like in any real roguelike, is common even for the experienced player and there's a major sense of satisfaction when you discover a new trick, enter a new dungeon or simply cave in the head of some nasty monster that has taken you all of your ammo, your power points and left you barely functional.

I started my journey back in 1995 on the Amiga playing this game made up of @ signs and & signs and wondering how such a bland, simple looking game could ever hope to hold my attention. 20 years on, new content has been added and colourful tiles presenting a much nicer GUI have arrived.

And one piece of advice.... never EVER eat a kobold... it's like Montezuma's revenge (wait, you might meet him) only worse!!!

reviewText: 'You find yourself in the bowels of a dank dungeon, your robes burned to ashes, bleeding from your wounds.  The dread beast that inflicted the wounds upon you lies smoldering before you, the last of your power expended upon its ruin.  Through the doorway that led you to this chamber, you hear a thunderous 'HARUMPH'.  This can only mean ruin.  You frantically search your belongings, desperate for salvation.  You pray to your God, but the ground quakes at your request, a stern denial from your patron deity.  A tremendous stomping grows nearer, and you fear that your time is short.  Sweat pouring down your bleeding face, you find a Wand of Digging in your pack, intact but depleted of charges, alongside your Wand of Door Creation.  Like a man gone mad, you plunge the Wand of Digging into your only potion of Booze, and cry out when the wand glows once more.  You fire it behind you, creating a vast tunnel wherein you dash for safety.  You zap your Wand of Door creation behind you, and with your faintly regained power Magically Lock the summoned door.  You run down your new corridor, seeking escape, only to find another dead end.  The impossibly heavy steps of the impending creature grow close now, as you huddle in the corner of your shelter.  The steps cease, you hold your breath in sheer terror, silently attempting to gather yourself in meditation and regain power.  An explosion of splinters erupts from the other side of your corridor, and the many eyed horror that approaches from the gloom freezes you in your place.  You think of Terinyo as the horror steps toward you, you think of the home you left behind.  Your fear gives way to darkness, the darkness to silence; Ancardia's greatest hope extinguished like a torch in the rain.'\n\nYou die.  You survive.  You learn. ADOM is a game that offers you a canvas upon which to design your own adventure.  Are you a hero?  A villain?  Do you aspire to seal the forces of Chaos away, or reign over it a mad God for eternity?  Are you a simple farmer, far from home?  A gambler, seeking the highest stakes casino in all the world?  Call it a roguelike, call it a fantasy role playing sandbox, call it a sadistic RNG exercise, ADOM is all that and far more.  No experience is perfect, games crash, characters are lost.  ADOM is mysterious, and you may puzzle at the Scroll of Dark Predictions in your inventory, or the Tract of Chaos you see on the ground.  You may wander to the Tower of Eternal Flames, and enter without caution.  You die.  You survive.  You learn.  ADOM is a game of mystery, a game of skill, a game of chance.  Distinct from its peers, beloved by its fanbase, and better than ever here on Steam.  Don't fear the learning curve, if you've whiled away hours exploring Morrowind, Baldur's Gate, Fallout, this game may be the gateway to a genre you've never given a thought to before, as it was for me.

reviewText:
ADOM by many measures, is one of the few classic roguelikes that started it all. In developement since 1994, and by reading over its history, I can say it has come a long way. This title can certainly hold its own right up  there with the best of modern games. Some may have you believe a single person (Thomas Biskup) built this, but as is stated in the credits, the end product is the result of thousands of peoples hard work and ideas. Certainly Mr. Biskup deserves the lion's share of credit, but compared to other indie titles, this is hardly something that came out of someones basement over the weekend.

Classic roguelikes are nearly infinite in replayability, and possibility. Sure, there is a certain trade-off between user interface, graphics, and learning curve that pays out with a giant world with metric tons of gameplay and fun. Yes, its difficult. Yes, you will need to read lots (thank you in-game manual). Yes, it is FUN.

Pros:
+Timeless game that has been shaped over 20 years, which is reflected by system complexity that goes unmatched in modern games.
+The ability to seemlessly (simply push F10) switch between classic ASCII and tiles.
+Tiles and music are beautifully done.
+Many modes that are all well recieved. In example, Crowd mode alters the difficulty of your game by how many Steam friends you have that play ADOM. This is fresh and certainly encourages community.
+++Highscores leaderboards!
+++Ghosts of your fallen Steam friends show up in your game lol.
+Both keyboard and mouse support. I find the control scheme very intuitive. The updated user interface is very nice IMO.
+In-depth tutorial.
+Great community.
+Super active developement.

Cons:
-Yeah there is a steep learning curve, but that only applies to people that are new to roguelikes. Get through it, or simply realize these types of games are not your cup of tea.

If you have any interest in PC gaming history at all, this title deserves to be in your library. What a gem. It amazes me how this classic has evolved over time and can still outcompete modern titles.

reviewText:
Ancient Domains of MysteryDeveloped by: Thomas Biskup , Jochen Terstiege , Zeno Rogue , Krzysztof Dycha , Lucas Dieguez
Published by: Thomas Biskup
Released:  16th Nov 2015

Impressions and thoughts:
ADOM is one of the 'Gods' of the traditional roguelike genre, starting as a MS DOS game in 1994, continually being  development to this day.  It features several dozen different dungeons, some with fixed layout and others randomly generated each time you play.  It also has an 'overworld' adventure map, which was an unique feature in ADOM's young days.

There are a lot of different character types you can make from a big selection of races and classes who can pursue multiple different endings.  Save the world from ChAoS as a Troll Paladin, or maybe take the place of the elder chaos god Andor Drakon as a Hurthling Farmer? Anything goes.

ADOM has always been and will continue to be freeware, downloadable from the developer site adom.de.  Recent features include the graphical Noteye tileset that vastly improves the visual appeal.

On Steam, the Deluxe version promises a slew of additional features, many of which at the time of this review several months after release have not been realized in the game.  This is a point worthy of critique.  The small development team working on ADOM have always done things in their own pace, which is perfectly fine for a freeware hobby project.  However with a Steam release comes expectations of promises being delivered on.  As much as I love the devs and the wonderful game they've created, this must be pointed out.  While ADOM is a complete game in its own right, the DELUXE version is far from complete.

That bit of complaining aside, ADOM is a beautiful game.  It is a brutal, oldschool roguelike with such a staggering depth that even with the community wiki on hand, it can take years to uncover all its tricks and secrets.  It will kill hundreds of characters, often just when you felt they were getting somewhere before you can even think about beating the whole game.  It has the replayability for the game to still be addicting to play for all those attempts, with all its character variations and random generated nature.  In fact, I recommend this game not for the story and reaching its ending, but for all the journeys your poor doomed characters embark on before they inevitably get crushed.

If you like turnbased dungeon crawling, traditional roguelikes with deep systems that you will keep learning new things in even after years of playing, ADOM comes strongly recommended.  However!  I would suggest playing the freeware version on adom.de first.  Unless you just want to support the developers of course (which you should!).  The Deluxe version of the game on Steam doesn't as of yet add much of features to justify a price tag.  Once implemented I think the Steam version will be safely recommended, as well.

First things first: Be prepared! ADOM is a demanding and difficult game with permadeath coming at you around every corner. Several secret handshakes that you just got to learn about the hard way. And it's not even really fair at all times. Also you will be consulting a wiki often.

However,

The sense of reward in this game is unparalleled. When you kill that Ancient Chaos Wyrm with one tremendous blow from your Vanquisher, getting revenge for those five other promising characters who died to him. Or when you finally get that one race/class/sign combo running properly that you've been trying for ages.

There is a lot of death in this game no doubt, but the huge variety you can have with character creation added to the general randomness of the game makes every adventure significantly different. The replay value of this game is immense. Dying means that you get to try something new once again!

As you start out, you might be spending as much time reading a wiki as you are playing. That's okay, there are no real spoilers in this game. Knowing everything beforehand does not really affect your experience in any negative way. And there is a fun sense of mystique; even after years of play you'll be learning new things.

The steam edition packs this classic of a game in a neat and functional package. Definitely worth the price when it comes to amount of gameplay. Also worth it for the veterans. Though if you are very particular to ascii graphics (though you can play this version in ascii aswell), you might not find enough new features as of yet.

Definitely one of the better games ever made!

reviewText:
Many games these days boast to have vast open worlds, open-ended gameplay and endless replayability - ADOM actually delivers.

- Background -

I first played ADOM in 2003. I've since spent hundreds of hours exploring the mysterious Drakalor Chain. ADOM is one of my all-time favourite games, and certainly the only game originally released in the 90's that I don't play for nostalgia - but because it is still fresh.

ADOM is an RPG in the true sense of the word: it does not impose restrictions on you. The problem I have with most RPGs these days is how they limit the player's actions. The choice between good and evil is often in fact the choice between the good and evil dialogue option. ADOM is different in that you can actually do whatever you want, be anyone you want to be. And doing whatever you want actually means something in ADOM, since the game has a ridiculously large amount of content. Really, it does.

- Gameplay -

In ADOM, first you'll create your character. Your character will be given a starsign that will have some effect on him/her. After that you'll choose your race, profession, talents etc. from a ton of options. These choises will guide you as you start your journey, but won't limit you as (or if) you progress.

As the game begins, you enter Drakalor Chain, a troubled valley with many mysteries to explore. From then on it's all up to you. Go to the nearest village and interact with the townsfolk or find your own path. Battle fierce beasts, learn incredible spells, rob stores, fight for money, make friends, embark on quests, search for artifacts, brew deadly poisons, control minds, barter items, cook food, worship your gods, play instruments, raise the dead, clean your ears...

And of course you'll die. You'll be drowned, burnt and crushed to death. You'll die of hunger and sickness and bloodloss. You'll accidentally kill yourself conducting dangerous magical experiments. You'll die as you are sacrificed to strange and terrible gods. You'll die and return. And maybe, just maybe you'll one day defeat the powers that plague Drakalor Chain. I never did, yet, but I'll keep on trying.

See you in the Caverns of Chaos!

reviewText:
The early game in ADOM constantly asks you to make risk vs reward decisions. Whether to stand and fight, or run away and heal. Whether to kick down a door and risk activating a trap, or come back later with a key. Whether to risk delving one level deeper, or travel to a safer location. Making the wrong call will often lead to an early death, but negotiate these issues and your character will be set up for the challenges that follow.

For newcomers to the game, I advise choosing a stong melee character (e.g. an orc fighter), and start in the tutorial dungeon to get used to the basics of moving around and hitting things with swords. This is what you'll be doing for the majority of the time, regardless of class. You can then let the complexities of the other mechanics seep in over time.

I used to play a lot of the ASCII version, but not so much recently. I'm already impressed with the new graphical tileset and other features which are in this version, and the game underneath is still the exciting combination of exploration and danger it always was.

reviewText: I learned the basics of this game about 1,5 years ago and have since then been playing it fairly regularly. Pride when you get out of a situation that looked completely desperate by using your wits, disbelief when you finally identify your stuff and see that you've been carrying around 2 (!!) amulets of life saving, anger at yourself when you lose that really promising character just because you didn't stop playing in time (when you noticed your eyes started itching and your vision got a bit blurry, but hey, you just couldn't leave the game at that point, no way...)\nI'm really no game expert, I don't have any comparison to other roguelikes or any other computer games for that matter. reviewText:
(TL:DR: great game and it is a finished game but it is not ready for a general steam audience)

I'm putting this as a positive review because I think ADOM is a great game which is lots of fun but there are lots of warnings I have to give to people who haven't played this game or old school roguelikes before.

(I came back to this review and really wanted to tone the review down because I think the dev is a great guy and it's a really fun game but I have to be honest: there are a lot of pretty big annoyances that will make people not used to the game regret buying it, and people do need to realize that development, while always ongoing, is not as rapid as some other games, and patience is required).


The game was greenlit a long time ago and wasn't released on steam until a year and a half later. The explanation for this was polishing the game for the general steam audience rather than the more forgiving hardcore old fans of the game. Despite this, it is not really ready for a general audience despite there being easily enough time to prepare it.

1. The game can crash: I experienced a crash within my first two hours of play. The game is permadeath but does autosave every 1000 turns. The problem is that in order to recover from a crash you have to know what you are doing and rename a certain file a certain way. The game is not programmed to realize it hasn't shut down cleanly so it can't help you.seems fixed

2. There is mouse control but it's not total, meaning you have to press keys sometimes. It's not easy to even predict when you'll have to press a key rather than being able to use the mouse.

3. The default keys are really bad from a HCI point of view (human-computer interaction): For example to rest to regain hp etc. until something disturbs you is w5 or w. That's a two key sequence for something you will be doing all the time. Even worse is the autoexplore which is w?. That's a two key sequence with the second key requiring shift! This for something you will also be doing constantly. auto-explore is now - (minus) (casting spells as shift z, (pick spell letter), direction is bad too although is being changed to non shifted z which is slightly better)

4. It is possible to redefine the keys but unless you are an old player of adom or go looking on forums you wouldn't know how to. You have to go and get the config key file from where the game saves game data to (as in not the base game directory, e.g. for me it's C:\Users\<username>\Documents\ADOM\adom_steam) edit it in a text editor (and you have to know how to) and then put it in the right directory.

5. There are certain features coming soon". They include things like points-based character creation and being able to choose your star sign. Despite these things really not taking very long at all to program
date: they have been languishing on todo lists for ages. One of these at least was used by the greenlight campaign as an example of something that would be exclusive to the steam version and yet somehow didn't get programmed in the year and a half between being greenlit and steam release. ADOM is one of the big classical roguelikes, with 20 years of development. I had played it before the kickstarted campaign for the graphical version and had enjoyed it then, and I enjoy it now even more. It just offers a lot of depth and complexety, I can really dive into the game. The world really feels alive. I also enjoyed TOME, the other great classical roguelike, but somehow I always preferred ADOM. TOME just feels more like game, with its MMO-like skills, while ADOM has the typical quirkiness and complexety of games like nethack, just with a persistent overworld and an actual story, which for me is more immersive.

I like the music, the tilesets and the many possible options, the mouse control. The loading times are pretty much non-existent, which isn't the case for TOME for example. But it still expects much the users to use the non-intuitive outdated old keyboard-shortcuts.

ADOM is hard and unforgiving. The new ingame tutorial doesn't change that. I would recommend reading the beginners guides on the wiki and the ingame manual. It's a game for people who have a lot of patience and are prepared to die early. I contrast to most rogue-lites and also many roguelikes, such as TOME, I always grow attached to my characters, so having them die is even more painful.

Tl;dr: ADOM is still one of the best games for roguelike fans who like depth and are prepared to die a lot and I am positvely surprised of the technical overhaul. But it's still nothing for people who simply want to explore a world and don't like reading manuals.

reviewText:
I *love* this game. I've been playing for almost 20 years and I'm still not bored of it. Massively recommended classic roguelike, now with prettified graphics and sound.

HOWEVER, you should be aware of a few things before you buy:
- Turn-based (Roguelike)
- Steep learning curve, including Permadeath (Roguelike)
- Tile graphics covering up an ASCII system (Roguelike)
- Somewhat archaic control system (but the best amongst the classic Roguelikes IMO, with decent inventory control)
- Awkward to play without a numpad - especially if you don't have an actual mouse. Not recommended for any but the biggest laptop keyboards.
- Just in case it wasn't really obvious, this is very much a thinking gamer's game. It has ZERO twitch.

And probably the worst point:
- Many new releases thusfar have included a fatal crash bug... although these are generally fixed in about 24 hours.

BUT...
If you're willing to persevere through this, you've got a game of almost unparalleled depth and enjoyment. SO much to learn, SO many different viable strategies, SO many different character builds, and SO much tension and excitement in a turn-based game.

TWENTY. YEARS.

Not bored.

I search for traps.

Wait...a game that's fully developed and GOOD?  What kind of dungeon is this?  IT'S ADOM!

Welcome to the only world you'll ever want to live in for the foreseeable future!  Filled with an amazing and detailed story, ADOM is the true definition of Rogue-like.  But unlike many other Roguelikes that you'll find on steam, Ancient Domains of Mystery really does make you worry about losing your character, while simultaneously making you want to start again the second you die.  From exploring caves to finishing quests for unique items, ADOM has something for everyone.  And now with its new (and totally optional) UI, it even has graphics for those who can't stand nethack.

I have been playing ADOM pre 1.0 release and I am SO happy to see this game brought to life.  The Creator Thomas Biskup has been working on this game for so long and each new release has had me crawling around in Ancardia looking at the new changes and updates.   Now that it's on Steam, I am happy to spend my money to support the ADOM crew and continue to keep this jewel alive.

I highly urge users to try to the ASCII version prior to playing with the graphical version.  I say this because it will absolutely help you understand the mechanics and probabilities of this game.  I don't personally care for the graphical version, but being a fan of skyrim and fallout, I can also understand the longing for something more than ASCII characters moving around.

I also highly recommend checking out the wikia.  The world of Ancardia is so full and detailed, that it will help you immensely to look up your class and race to see what fun specialties they afford you!  Many have fun skills you can only have as certain races.  Be prepared to immerse yourself and realize how much fun the game can be!

reviewText:
One of the major predecessors to the 'adventure roguelike' genre has finally come to Steam! I have been playing this game for more years than my 'time played' would suggest, and for people who love a good roguelike RPG, I can honestly say that I have yet to find a better one. A huge world (for a roguelike), many quests, secrets, Easter Eggs, character customization, achievements, challenges.... this game is an absolute *gem*.

Be aware: like all good(?) roguelikes, this is not a game for the faint of heart. Even with an 'easymode' to it, it can have a very steep learning curve, and your deaths will be spectacular. A lot of weight can hang on the Will Of The RNG. The right weapon at the right time, or the wrong roll at the wrong time, can make or break a game. Be aware that while skill counts heavily, it's all too possible to find yourself in a situation where one mislaid trap can be the diffeence between life and death.

It's a game I wouldn't trade for the world, though, and one that is worth every penny paid for it. If you're a fan of the roguelike genre, this is one not to be missed. Don't pass this up!

No, I'm here because I have this bottle of wine and this wonderful game and all I wanted, besides rambling on Steam, was to give my thanks. So here's to you Mr. Biskup! It's like learning to juggle, every time adding one more ball to an already incredible act. Even death is sometimes fun. Last night I laughed as I died, heavily poisoned, right after emerging victorious close to HMV. The Gods were tired of my nagging to them and chose not to answer me. Anyway, to all of you trying to decide the game's worth based on Steam reviews: get it, pour a glass of wine and join me in my quest to master this wonderful game.

ADOM is the first steam game I have ever returned.   I typically read many reviews beforehand - so it's not necessary to return games.  In the case of ADOM, most of the reviews fail to mention any of the issues associated with the numerous keybindings required to play the game in an enjoyable fashion.  I didn't notice until after returning the game that most of the negative reviews were unfairly down voted for mentioning critical issues associated with poor mouse controls.

The controls are clunky and the game requires too much memorization of key bindings to play.  Most of the positive reviews posted on Steam are likely from long time players who memorized the long list of key bindings a long time ago.  For new players - this will likely be a highly unpleasant experience because of the aforementioned poor user interface and reliance on key bindings.

There are free versions of this game that you can try out before buying.  I highly recommend any new player to this game to download a free version and try out the controls first hand before purchasing on Steam.  You will easily discover if the controls bother you or not.   Like the other reviews that mention ADOM's outdated reliance keybindings and clunky controls, I expect my review to be down-voted.  I'm okay with that if it means saving other Steam users money.  The limited time listed of me playing this game is actually overstating my time spent on this game.  90% of that time was actually spent reading up on one of the many outdated keybindings required to play before deciding to uninstall the game.

Thomas Biskup absolutely deserves every penny of my money.

reviewText:
This is my absolute favourite rogue like. I have been playing for at least 10 years and the new steam version adds some welcome changes.

I love this game simply because it has all the awsome features you would expect from a roguelike but with a world map.
The world map is always the same and features a lot of entrances to dungeons and villages, each being different in sometimes a variety of ways, and for the most part are randomized every game. this leaves you free to pick and choose which quests you want to take. Once you have figured out a lot of the early quests you can choose to skip the ones in which the rewards do not interest you.

My one criticism of this game is that the religion system sucks. It's not interesting, the rewards for becoming uber pious are kind of lackluster when i consider how grindy and unenjoyable reaching that point is. Fortunately it is not necesary to concern yourself with it. I compare this game in this regard to dungeon crawl and IVAN which both have interesting and fun religion systems.

Another aspect of this game that i like compared to other roguelikes, such as dungeon crawl, is that the skill system is very rewarding. some skills are passive and just buff your character but others have specific applications.
you can pick pockets, pick locks, build bridges, craft arrows, tame animals, brew potions, smith armour...
For me this adds a layer of character that helps me role play.

I recomend this game however if you do not have any experience with roguelikes i suggest you do some reading about the genre as this game is brutal and, other than the games basic mechanics, this is mostly a trial by fire.
I am adamant about not using guides or cheating, however this game is so brutal that despite knowing all i need to know i have never managed to win even a single time despite using the adom guidebook and perusing forums for additional insight.

reviewText:
The first RPG I've played, and one I still come back to every now and then. I've been excited ever since the crowdfunding campaing, and been singing praises of this game ever since. It's brutal, hard and random, yes, but such is the nature of TRUE rogue-likes.

Deluxe version gives you the options to lower the difficulty for more casual of players, so they can get enjoyment out of this game as well. Even giving you option to properly save your game, unlike the normal mode, where your game save is tied to your characters life, once character dies, it's gone. This is something not available in the free version. More on that later.

But the true meat of this game comes from flexibility of the combat... You have your basic Melee, Ranged and Magic attacks, but you also can use Mindcraft, companions, special race/class abilities and alchemy to name a few varied methods of dealing damage. But you can in turn take damage from ridiculous stuff among others, and get killed in many, many ways, including getting crushed by dungeon, whipping yourself to death, getting sacrificed to one of many gods, having too much stuff in your inventory and my personal favorite: Getting eaten by grue. Also, you can get killed before you even move (or take your first step) with certain race/class combinations on certain day.

There are plenty of static elements in game that stay same from game to game, but majority of the dungeons are randomly generated, keeping you on your toes every time. No two games are the same, which makes this game highly replayable.

Deluxe version of ADOM is not only worth your money, but as it gets more features, which will keep coming until the Creator of this game feels this game is complete (and moves onto the Sequel) makes this game truly worthwhile. But if you are not certain of getting the Deluxe version yet, you can always download the Free version of this game from ADOM homepage, and try it out as much you want. The base game is the same regardless, but There are bunch of nifty features that will not be in the free versions ever. But if you so desire, you can run the newest free version of this game on your Amiga or old MS-Dos computers. That's how old-school this game is.

Another aspect of this game that i like compared to other roguelikes, such as dungeon crawl, is that the skill system is very rewarding. some skills are passive and just buff your character but others have specific applications.
you can pick pockets, pick locks, build bridges, craft arrows, tame animals, brew potions, smith armour...

I recomend this game however if you do not have any experience with roguelikes i suggest you do some reading about the genre as this game is brutal and, other than the games basic mechanics, this is mostly a trial by fire.

reviewText:
My four brothers and I have been playing ADOM since about 2000. We have dedicated uncountable hours to this game, improving our talents/skill choices, learning which monsters are dangerous (nearly all of them in their own way, even as food!), how to not starve to death, how to infer properties of unidentified items, how to make your deity happy (very useful), to always eat ogre and blink dog corpses, and that you should never attempt any alchemy as an amateur no matter how innocent appearing (not even mixing water and carrot juice).

Yet not once have any of us beat the game. Some of us have gotten close a couple times, but no cigar.  Unlike the vast majority of all games, beating this game without scum saving is truly a respectable achievement and the journey itself will yield many super-intense close calls.

Despite the difficulty, we still play it and always come back to it. The ADOM world has so much depth, playing the game is really like exploring a new world.

ADOM is probably one of the best RPGs in existence. If you can look past the simple graphics and turn based play, this game will yield many, many hours of fun.

I was a fan of the original way back in the day, played it constantly. Wrote my own program to auto-backup the saves so I could cheat permadeath when I wanted to. I have played many dungeon crawl games, including Rogue, the OG of the genre. Out of them, this is one of the best.

A large open world (for the genre) full of quests and NPCs. There is plenty to do and see in ADOM as well as a large selection of Class/Race combanations. The mechanics are perfect. This game was created based on PnP rpgs like DnD, and attempts to recreate this as much as possible. There are a ton of hidden rolls, and many are refrenced in the text. The text really makes it feel like a tabletop rpg, well written and really sets the tone.

ADOM is also Random and unpredictable. You may die on the way to your first town, killed by enemies you stood no chance against, or kick down a door  to find a large demon ready to rip your head off. With permadeath on it is a hardcore dungeon delvers wet dream come true. This game is hard.

But now there are options to turn certain features, like permadeath, off. This opens the door for people like me, who enjoy the style, but dont like always playing a hardcore character. It also makes it easier to really enjoy the story and world without fear of losing your character . The graphics are not cutting edge, and I for one am glad. This is the update the game needed. Havent fiddled with the other game modes, but I theres just so much to do. I am also glad development seems to be continueing, so there may be more content to come.

So there you go, I love this game, totally worth my money.  If you are into old skool Rogue-Likes and value depth over fancy graphics I think you will too.



ps~Thank you Thomas, for all the hours I have played your game over the years, I bought this almost as soon as it came out on steam, and you deserve every penny. GG

reviewText:
After 10 years - give or take - Ancient Domains of Mystery still wakes that primal excitement in this quite cynical gamer.

ADOM is one of the first true roguelikes among Nethack and the like but was the only one of those that made me sit on my chair, scratching my hair with the decisions the game made me do, or the sheer amount of options it presented. I was stunned that you really needed almost the whole keyboard to play the game and it sure took time to learn most of the quirks. Back then the game was presented in ASCII aka by symbols like letters and numbers. Plain 'g' for goblin and 'k' for kobold.

This new Steam version has graphics in form of a tileset tho, so you don't have to learn how to read" the game first even though it doesn't remove the fact that you still have to master them buttons. I think the tileset is very decent taking concideration the scale of the game and the amount of classes/races/weapons/etc there is.

The UI sure feels clunky though and I recomend taking your time to read through everything the first time. After generating few characters and painfully losing them you'll surely get the hang of it and the gameplay get's much smoother and faster. It's not as difficult as Dwarf Fortress but in a whole new level compared to i.e. Dungeons of Dredmor if that helps anything.

I might add and edit the review if needed but for now I just wanted to welcome my old friend to Steam and give it a nice 9/10 review."

reviewText:
As someone who has been playing ADOM since last century, I highly reccomend this game. But be warned, it is not a simple game where you will sit down for five minutes to flick birds at stuff. This game requires time and patience of you, but it gives back as much as you give.

For new players, a few tips: you have a deity, and you should pray when things get tough. Buy food if you didn't start with much, and especially have food for long treks through the wilderness. Anyone can put a madman out of his misery - a true hero will find a way to heal him. Giant inscects have hard shells, and you may need to swing like a berserker to cut through. Your first mindcrafter will be killed by a stone block; do not be angry when this happens. Until you understand how altars work, do not step on black ones.

And keep at it. Yes, you will die a lot. Expect your high scores to fill up with level 1-7 heroes before you really start to master this game. Winning this game is not an eventual certainty. It is a glorious achievement.

Axes high!

I had been playing the graphically simplified version available at the original since 1998/1999.

It was one of the best ASCII roguelikes then and now, with all the new stuff it has become just THE game I am playing all the time...

But let me explain WHY do I not need any other games.

ADOM at Steam gives me the true feeling of constant growth, immersion, improvement, a shifting challenge system that changes constantly and is always just a bit less difficult than the impossible...

The graphics and sound are there - no less, no more. However, for an old ASCII fan like me, they create a nice atmosphere in a quite smart way as they are no less and no more than a formal aesthetic addition to the already complex, deep and well implemented game system.

What I do not like - actually what I HAAAAATE is the fact that I had to set the autosave backup file to 50 game turns, as - but for save scumming - I would have lost EVERY save file I had tried to recover... unfortunately, the game would often crash while trying to save the game. Some forum members say it is just a paranoidal behavior, but should I choose between frustration and safety, I definitely aim for the second one.

What I do like - nothing less and nothing more than all the features of the good old Ancient Domains Of Mystery" from the late '90s

reviewText:
ADOM (Ancient Domains of Mystery)  is a roguelike adventure game, developed by a team of 5 people. This review is coming from someone who has not played the original games in the series and has no prior knowledge, and from someone who didn’t grow up playing this type of game either. Please bear that in mind with this review.

Gameplay is like any other roguelike game, where you get to choose from an array of different characters, and develop levels, statistics and skills as you progress.  The game is played from a top down angel and is very heavily weighted towards stats and what choices you make in whether you succeed or fail.  The game’s tutorial absolutely bombards you with way too much information which personally left more confused compared to when I first started. The controls and UI are quite possibly the worst I have ever experienced in a game too. There is quite literally a different button for every single mechanic in the game. This game made me feel sufficiently stupid because of how much jumble there is on any one screen at any time. The game was telling me to use buttons that I don’t think I have ever used on this keyboard. I am surprised this is one of the most popular roguelikes ever just from going off the usability of the game thus far.

The graphics are bad, there is no way around it and anyone who says otherwise is purely saying it from a nostalgia standpoint.  The pictures in the screen shots are definitely not what the game looks like on my screen, and I was playing the game in 4k.

I am still stuck in the tutorial of the game, because of being dumbfounded with the controls and the amount of information being thrown at me but this game if you manage to get into it, will offer you hours and hours of content with a very high replay ability factor also being the main reason behind this.

I am fully expecting this review to not be very popular given that I have reviewed it before even getting out of the tutorial; and I am clearly missing something about this game since it is so highly rated. But for me, having not grown up playing this type of game, and from someone who is not able to take in abundant amounts of information and learning the most whacky confusing control scheme, I simply cannot recommend it. It is possibly a generation thing, but if you mostly agree with my reviews and enjoy the same games I do, then you may want to eerie on the side of caution when trying this out as it is simply a game I did not enjoy at all.

reviewText:
So after 52 hours of play I'm finally writing a review, and then giving up and moving on to something else.  There is a small list of reasons, but it comes down to the fact that the game just isn't much fun.  Perhaps that's a symptom of being 'roguelike', perhaps not.

Pros
- easy to get started, play a while and then stop.  ei no load times, no startup ads to watch, no fancy graphic splash screen

Cons
-  Vast majority of games end in you dying.  Since this is permadeath all the time invested is lost.  Period.
- Most of the things that kill young characters (hunger, traps you can't detect on doors you must go through), poisons you can't cure, monsters that one-hit-kill and who are also faster than you are) you have no possibility of avoiding.  The game doesn't attempt to balance things, it mostly just rolls RNG's and eventually you die.
- Your character rarely knows anything about the equipment/potion/buffs.  You could die with a potion of healing in your possession and have no possibility of finding out.
- Even if you choose a class that allows you to see cursed/uncursed status, the game has undetectable cursed items to saddle your character with usless sh*t.
- Game does a very poor job at allowing balanced characters.
- Too many things completely invulnerable to player attacks/spells, and very little chance to determine what could be effective against them before you die.
- If you need something (food particularly, healing, a decent weapon, an identify scroll) you will never find it.  If you don't need it, the stuff drops like rain.  And of course this lack is going to kill you.

Pretty much the game is more of a fancy RNG, rather that someting that is fun.   Some will find this fun, most people will find it frustrating and unrewarding.  And the fact that it kills you repeatedly without any possibilty of not dying makes it more fruitless.
